subject: Re: [junit] INQUIRY: How to show individual test progress
msgSnippet: ... JUnit was written to support test-first programming. When writing code test-first, tests cannot be that slow. Now you know why JUnit makes no room for such
messageBody:
Sangretu wrote:
>
>
> At first, I thought I could just extend a few classes and add a second
> progress bar to the GUI to show the progress of an individual test
> above the overall progress (much like install programs show the
> copying of a specific file next to the overall copying status).
>
> This proved to be much more trouble than I expected. Sure, I could
> extend TestCase to periodically call a function in its TestResult
> (oops, it has no reference to it!), which would then propogate to the
> TestListener, and then somehow output the data. But...no. That was SO
> much more work than it seemed like it should have been. Too many
> private elements, too much reflection.
>
> But it seems like a useful feature. Perhaps one that others might have
> explored in the past. Has anyone looked at this? Is there an extension
> out there that implements it?

JUnit was written to support test-first programming.

When writing code test-first, tests cannot be that slow.

Now you know why JUnit makes no room for such a feature.

You can easily build your own test runner with that feature built in. I
think the community would like to have it -- at least, the ones doing
integration testing or testing legacy code, where they have tests that
take more than fractions of a second.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
